channel.title: IDEs
channel.description: What are IDEs? I have only heard so much about them, and that "much" is very little.

item.title: IDEs
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:7, topic:388514”][quote author=Epic Steve link=topic=484337.msg3548790#msg3548790 date=1301357752]
IntelliJ IDEA.
[/quote]

Used the trial, didn’t want to pay for it.

I just use Eclipse and netbeans. Only thing I don’t like about them is the extra “bulk” it adds for the workspace.[/quote]
Get the community version. It’s free and it’s perfect for what anyone here will need.

Get IntelliJ IDEA. Imo, it’s by far the best.

Read full topic

item.title: IDEs
item.dc:creator: @Echo3 Echo_
item.description:
@Echo3 wrote:

Notepad++ is a lot easier if you are just editing existing code, but if you are actually writing your own code an IDE is your best friend.

ziplock:

I program with C# and Visual Studio constantly reminds me of every single method, variable, package, everything and my memory isn’t the best so that’s wonderful. It also checks for errors constantly, so it cuts down the debugging time significantly.

Visual C# is a great piece of software

Read full topic

item.title: IDEs
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:15, topic:388514”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=484337.msg3555585#msg3555585 date=1301859552]

A necessity.

Not true, I do better in Notepad++.
[/quote]

I still think it classifies as an IDE. It does do color coating etc.

I just don’t understand how people can program without a sophisticated IDE. The constant debugging would be so rough.[/quote]
I actually enjoy it when I get a major bug, makes my brain work harder.

Read full topic

Well I have Eclipse, Netbeans, and Notepad++, I like Netbeans and Notepad++. But thats just me, I don’t know much about Java, but I’d like to know all about the language, maybe even program it as a career if I like it so much. The only Java I know is from programming RSPS.

item.title: IDEs
item.dc:creator: @usman555 usman555
item.description:
@usman555 wrote:

IDEs (Integrated Development Environment) are programs that help you program in a given chosen language. They offer built in compilers, fix obvious mistakes, and pretty much help you program, like I just said. I use Netbeans (used Eclipse but I think Netbeans is better).

Read full topic

item.title: IDEs
item.dc:creator: @Wyrmcabbage Wyrmcabbage
item.description:
@Wyrmcabbage wrote:

An integrated development environment (IDE) (also known as integrated design environment or integrated debugging environment) is a software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development. An IDE normally consists of:

* a source code editor
* a compiler and/or an interpreter
* build automation tools
* a debugger

Sometimes a version control system and various tools are integrated to simplify the construction of a GUI. Many modern IDEs also have a class browser, an object inspector, and a class hierarchy diagram, for use with object-oriented software development.

Straight from Wikipedia. Basically, it’s a text editor that can compile programs automatically (by this I mean you don’t have to cd and javac etc.), generally highlights your errors (and offers you ways to fix them) and allow you to easily create packages. Personally, I couldn’t live without one.

Read full topic

Community Edition? Free & Open Source.

JetBrains

Download IntelliJ IDEA: The Java IDE for Professional Developers by JetBrains

Code-centric IDE, focused on your productivity. Full Java EE support, deep code understanding, best debugger, refactorings, everything right out of the box...
